lines.text: Enter SIR TOBY BELCH, SIR ANDREW, and FABIAN

lines.speaker: sir toby belch
lines.text: Come thy ways, Signior Fabian.

lines.speaker: fabian
lines.text: Nay, I'll come: if I lose a scruple of this sport, let me be boiled to death with melancholy.

lines.speaker: sir toby belch
lines.text: Wouldst thou not be glad to have the niggardly rascally sheep-biter come by some notable shame?

lines.speaker: fabian
lines.text: I would exult, man: you know, he brought me out o' favour with my lady about a bear-baiting here.

lines.speaker: sir toby belch
lines.text: To anger him we'll have the bear again; and we will fool him black and blue: shall we not, Sir Andrew?

lines.speaker: sir andrew
lines.text: An we do not, it is pity of our lives.

lines.speaker: sir toby belch
lines.text: Here comes the little villain. How now, my metal of India!
Enter MARIA

lines.speaker: maria
lines.text: Get ye all three into the box-tree: Malvolio's coming down this walk: he has been yonder i' the sun practising behavior to his own shadow this half hour: observe him, for the love of mockery; for I know this letter will make a contemplative idiot of him. Close, in the name of jesting! Lie thou there, for here comes the trout that must be caught with tickling.
Throws down a letter
Exit
Enter MALVOLIO

lines.speaker: malvolio
lines.text: 'Tis but fortune; all is fortune. Maria once told me she did affect me: and I have heard herself come thus near, that, should she fancy, it should be one of my complexion. Besides, she uses me with a more exalted respect than any one else that follows her. What should I think on't?

lines.speaker: sir toby belch
lines.text: Here's an overweening rogue!

lines.speaker: fabian
lines.text: O, peace! Contemplation makes a rare turkey-cock of him: how he jets under his advanced plumes!

lines.speaker: sir andrew
lines.text: 'Slight, I could so beat the rogue!

lines.speaker: sir toby belch
lines.text: Peace, I say.

lines.speaker: malvolio
lines.text: To be Count Malvolio!

lines.speaker: sir toby belch
lines.text: Ah, rogue!

lines.speaker: sir andrew
lines.text: Pistol him, pistol him.

lines.speaker: sir toby belch
lines.text: Peace, peace!

lines.speaker: malvolio
lines.text: There is example for't; the lady of the Strachy married the yeoman of the wardrobe.

lines.speaker: sir andrew
lines.text: Fie on him, Jezebel!

lines.speaker: fabian
lines.text: O, peace! now he's deeply in: look how imagination blows him.

lines.speaker: malvolio
lines.text: Having been three months married to her, sitting in my state,--

lines.speaker: sir toby belch
lines.text: O, for a stone-bow, to hit him in the eye!

lines.speaker: malvolio
lines.text: Calling my officers about me, in my branched velvet gown; having come from a day-bed, where I have left Olivia sleeping,--

lines.speaker: sir toby belch
lines.text: Fire and brimstone!

lines.speaker: fabian
lines.text: O, peace, peace!

lines.speaker: malvolio
lines.text: And then to have the humour of state; and after a demure travel of regard, telling them I know my place as I would they should do theirs, to for my kinsman Toby,--

lines.speaker: sir toby belch
lines.text: Bolts and shackles!

lines.speaker: fabian
lines.text: O peace, peace, peace! now, now.

lines.speaker: malvolio
lines.text: Seven of my people, with an obedient start, make out for him: I frown the while; and perchance wind up watch, or play with my--some rich jewel. Toby approaches; courtesies there to me,--

lines.speaker: sir toby belch
lines.text: Shall this fellow live?

lines.speaker: fabian
lines.text: Though our silence be drawn from us with cars, yet peace.

lines.speaker: malvolio
lines.text: I extend my hand to him thus, quenching my familiar smile with an austere regard of control,--

lines.speaker: sir toby belch
lines.text: And does not Toby take you a blow o' the lips then?

lines.speaker: malvolio
lines.text: Saying, 'Cousin Toby, my fortunes having cast me on your niece give me this prerogative of speech,'--

lines.speaker: sir toby belch
lines.text: What, what?

lines.speaker: malvolio
lines.text: 'You must amend your drunkenness.'

lines.speaker: sir toby belch
lines.text: Out, scab!

lines.speaker: fabian
lines.text: Nay, patience, or we break the sinews of our plot.

lines.speaker: malvolio
lines.text: 'Besides, you waste the treasure of your time with a foolish knight,'--

lines.speaker: sir andrew
lines.text: That's me, I warrant you.

lines.speaker: malvolio
lines.text: 'One Sir Andrew,'--

lines.speaker: sir andrew
lines.text: I knew 'twas I; for many do call me fool.

lines.speaker: malvolio
lines.text: What employment have we here?
Taking up the letter

lines.speaker: fabian
lines.text: Now is the woodcock near the gin.

lines.speaker: sir toby belch
lines.text: O, peace! and the spirit of humour intimate reading aloud to him!

lines.speaker: malvolio
lines.text: By my life, this is my lady's hand these be her very C's, her U's and her T's and thus makes she her great P's. It is, in contempt of question, her hand.

lines.speaker: sir andrew
lines.text: Her C's, her U's and her T's: why that?

lines.speaker: malvolio
lines.text: [Reads]  'To the unknown beloved, this, and my good wishes:'--her very phrases! By your leave, wax. Soft! and the impressure her Lucrece, with which she uses to seal: 'tis my lady. To whom should this be?

lines.speaker: fabian
lines.text: This wins him, liver and all.

lines.speaker: malvolio
lines.text: [Reads] Jove knows I love: But who? Lips, do not move; No man must know. 'No man must know.' What follows? the numbers altered! 'No man must know:' if this should be thee, Malvolio?

lines.speaker: sir toby belch
lines.text: Marry, hang thee, brock!

lines.speaker: malvolio
lines.text: [Reads] I may command where I adore; But silence, like a Lucrece knife, With bloodless stroke my heart doth gore: M, O, A, I, doth sway my life.

lines.speaker: fabian
lines.text: A fustian riddle!

lines.speaker: sir toby belch
lines.text: Excellent wench, say I.

lines.speaker: malvolio
lines.text: 'M, O, A, I, doth sway my life.' Nay, but first, let me see, let me see, let me see.

lines.speaker: fabian
lines.text: What dish o' poison has she dressed him!

lines.speaker: sir toby belch
lines.text: And with what wing the staniel cheques at it!

lines.speaker: malvolio
lines.text: 'I may command where I adore.' Why, she may command me: I serve her; she is my lady. Why, this is evident to any formal capacity; there is no obstruction in this: and the end,--what should that alphabetical position portend? If I could make that resemble something in me,--Softly! M, O, A, I,--

lines.speaker: sir toby belch
lines.text: O, ay, make up that: he is now at a cold scent.

lines.speaker: fabian
lines.text: Sowter will cry upon't for all this, though it be as rank as a fox.

lines.speaker: malvolio
lines.text: M,--Malvolio; M,--why, that begins my name.

lines.speaker: fabian
lines.text: Did not I say he would work it out? the cur is excellent at faults.

lines.speaker: malvolio
lines.text: M,--but then there is no consonancy in the sequel; that suffers under probation A should follow but O does.

lines.speaker: fabian
lines.text: And O shall end, I hope.

lines.speaker: sir toby belch
lines.text: Ay, or I'll cudgel him, and make him cry O!

lines.speaker: malvolio
lines.text: And then I comes behind.

lines.speaker: fabian
lines.text: Ay, an you had any eye behind you, you might see more detraction at your heels than fortunes before you.

lines.speaker: malvolio
lines.text: M, O, A, I; this simulation is not as the former: and yet, to crush this a little, it would bow to me, for every one of these letters are in my name. Soft! here follows prose. 'If this fall into thy hand, revolve. In my stars I am above thee; but be not afraid of greatness: some are born great, some achieve greatness, and some have greatness thrust upon 'em. Thy Fates open their hands; let thy blood and spirit embrace them; and, to inure thyself to what thou art like to be, cast thy humble slough and appear fresh. Be opposite with a kinsman, surly with servants; let thy tongue tang arguments of state; put thyself into the trick of singularity: she thus advises thee that sighs for thee. Remember who commended thy yellow stockings, and wished to see thee ever cross-gartered: I say, remember. Go to, thou art made, if thou desirest to be so; if not, let me see thee a steward still, the fellow of servants, and not worthy to touch Fortune's fingers. Farewell. She that would alter services with thee, THE FORTUNATE-UNHAPPY.' Daylight and champaign discovers not more: this is open. I will be proud, I will read politic authors, I will baffle Sir Toby, I will wash off gross acquaintance, I will be point-devise the very man. I do not now fool myself, to let imagination jade me; for every reason excites to this, that my lady loves me. She did commend my yellow stockings of late, she did praise my leg being cross-gartered; and in this she manifests herself to my love, and with a kind of injunction drives me to these habits of her liking. I thank my stars I am happy. I will be strange, stout, in yellow stockings, and cross-gartered, even with the swiftness of putting on. Jove and my stars be praised! Here is yet a postscript. 'Thou canst not choose but know who I am. If thou entertainest my love, let it appear in thy smiling; thy smiles become thee well; therefore in my presence still smile, dear my sweet, I prithee.' Jove, I thank thee: I will smile; I will do everything that thou wilt have me.
Reads
Reads
Exit

lines.speaker: fabian
lines.text: I will not give my part of this sport for a pension of thousands to be paid from the Sophy.

lines.speaker: sir toby belch
lines.text: I could marry this wench for this device.

lines.speaker: sir andrew
lines.text: So could I too.

lines.speaker: sir toby belch
lines.text: And ask no other dowry with her but such another jest.

lines.speaker: sir andrew
lines.text: Nor I neither.

lines.speaker: fabian
lines.text: Here comes my noble gull-catcher.
Re-enter MARIA

lines.speaker: sir toby belch
lines.text: Wilt thou set thy foot o' my neck?

lines.speaker: sir andrew
lines.text: Or o' mine either?

lines.speaker: sir toby belch
lines.text: Shall I play my freedom at traytrip, and become thy bond-slave?

lines.speaker: sir andrew
lines.text: I' faith, or I either?

lines.speaker: sir toby belch
lines.text: Why, thou hast put him in such a dream, that when the image of it leaves him he must run mad.

lines.speaker: maria
lines.text: Nay, but say true; does it work upon him?

lines.speaker: sir toby belch
lines.text: Like aqua-vitae with a midwife.

lines.speaker: maria
lines.text: If you will then see the fruits of the sport, mark his first approach before my lady: he will come to her in yellow stockings, and 'tis a colour she abhors, and cross-gartered, a fashion she detests; and he will smile upon her, which will now be so unsuitable to her disposition, being addicted to a melancholy as she is, that it cannot but turn him into a notable contempt. If you will see it, follow me.

lines.speaker: sir toby belch
lines.text: To the gates of Tartar, thou most excellent devil of wit!

lines.speaker: sir andrew
lines.text: I'll make one too.
Exeunt
